title: Australia To Recognise Palestinian State By September In UN: Australian PM Anthony Albanese
UK Homelessness Minister Quits After Making Her Own Tenants Homeless
summary: UK Homelessness Minister Quits After Making Her Own Tenants Homeless Authored by Thomas Brooke via Remix News, Rushanara Ali has resigned from her role as Minister for Homelessness in Keir Starmer‚Äôs left-wing government following reports that she removed tenants from her east...
fullContent: UK Homelessness Minister Quits After Making Her Own Tenants Homeless Authored by Thomas Brooke via Remix News, Rushanara Ali has resigned from her role as Minister for Homelessness in Keir Starmer‚Äôs left-wing government following reports that she removed tenants from her east London townhouse and relisted the property with a ¬£700-per-month rent increase. The revelations, first reported by the i Paper, raised concerns about a perceived conflict between Ali‚Äôs personal actions as a landlord and her public stance on housing policy. Bangladeshi-born Ali, who represents Bethnal Green and Stepney, submitted her resignation to Prime Minister Keir Starmer in a letter late on Thursday. She wrote, ‚ÄúIt is with a heavy heart that I offer you my resignation as a Minister,‚Äù and emphasized that she had always followed legal requirements, stating, ‚ÄúI believe I took my responsibilities and duties seriously, and the facts demonstrate this.‚Äù It has been an honour to have served in this Labour Government. To avoid any further distraction for the government, I have resigned as a Minister. My letter to the Prime Minister.https://t.co/fOes7m3cUH pic.twitter.com/TNJIXxzhWU ‚Äî Rushanara Ali MP üíô (@rushanaraali) August 7, 2025 The MP said she was stepping down because her continued presence in the role would be ‚Äúa distraction from the ambitious work of the government.‚Äù She cited supposed achievements made during her tenure, including tackling rough sleeping, strengthening democracy, and developing a pathway to end the war in Gaza. It is unclear why a homelessness minister elected by Brits in the United Kingdom considered the war in Gaza to be on her list of priorities. Ali has previously spoken out against landlords who exploit private renters and supported Labour‚Äôs upcoming Renters‚Äô Rights Bill, which will bar landlords from relisting properties at higher rents within six months of ending a tenancy to sell. A source close to Ali claimed the tenants were told their lease would not be renewed and were offered the option of staying on a rolling contract. The source said the house was initially put up for sale, and only relisted for rent after a buyer was not found. In response to her resignation, Prime Minister Keir Starmer thanked Ali for her work in government. ‚ÄúYour diligent work at the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government, including your efforts to put in measures to repeal the Vagrancy Act, will have a significant impact,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúI know you will continue to support the Government from the backbenches and represent the best interests of your constituents in Bethnal Green and Stepney.‚Äù Read more here... Tyler Durden Mon, 08/11/2025 - 02:45

title: The Price Of Being Half A Superpower
summary: The Price Of Being Half A Superpower Authored by Tamuz Itai via The Epoch Times, In July 2025, the European Union signed a landmark trade agreement with the United States. President Donald Trump described it as ‚Äúthe biggest deal ever made.‚Äù On paper, it looked like a win-win.
fullContent: The Price Of Being Half A Superpower Authored by Tamuz Itai via The Epoch Times, In July 2025, the European Union signed a landmark trade agreement with the United States. President Donald Trump described it as ‚Äúthe biggest deal ever made.‚Äù On paper, it looked like a win-win. But in policy circles across Europe, it landed more like a warning shot than a celebration. The core terms were stark: The EU agreed to impose a flat 15 percent tariff on all goods it exports to the U.S.‚Äîmore than the 10 percent the UK deal got‚Äîincluding autos, auto parts, pharmaceuticals, and semiconductors. Crucially, steel, aluminum, and copper exports will remain subject to punitive 50 percent tariffs. In return, the United States will pay zero tariffs on all American exports to Europe, covering industrial goods, agricultural products, and digital services. Perhaps more striking were the European purchase commitments. Under the deal, the EU pledged to import $750 billion of U.S. energy products‚Äîliquefied natural gas (LNG), crude oil, and refined fuels‚Äîby 2028, along with substantial volumes of semiconductors and industrial inputs. Brussels also committed to facilitating $600 billion in new European investment into the United States over the course of President Trump‚Äôs second term. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen framed the agreement as necessary pragmatism. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre known as a tough negotiator and dealmaker,‚Äù she told Trump, adding that the deal ‚Äúdelivers stability and predictability.‚Äù But her tone was notably defensive. When pressed on the 15 percent tariff for European carmakers, she conceded it was ‚Äùthe best we could get.‚Äù German Chancellor Friedrich Merz struck a similar note: relief over avoiding a full trade rupture, but no illusion about the pain to come. ‚ÄúMore simply wasn‚Äôt achievable,‚Äù he said of a better outcome. Across the continent, the reaction was muted. Belgium‚Äôs Prime Minister called it a ‚Äúmoment of relief but not of celebration.‚Äù France‚Äôs Minister for European Affairs described the deal as ‚Äúunbalanced.‚Äù Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n offered perhaps the most vivid summation: ‚ÄúTrump ate Ursula von der Leyen for breakfast.‚Äù Veteran British journalist Andrew Neil, with a dash of post-Brexit schadenfreude, pointed out that the UK had negotiated a ‚Äúfar better deal‚Äù‚Äîunshackled, as it were, from Brussels. But this wasn‚Äôt just a debate over tariffs. For many observers, the real question was structural: How did a bloc of 27 nations, with 450 million people and immense economic weight, end up looking like a junior partner in negotiations? The answer lies in the long, unfinished story of European integration‚Äîand the strategic costs of building power without consolidating it. The Stealth Path to Unity The European project was never just about economics. From its earliest postwar visionaries like Jean Monnet and Robert Schuman, the idea was that lasting peace and prosperity in Europe required deeper political union. But the path chosen was gradual and elite-driven. Instead of launching a public constitutional process like the United States in 1787, which demanded buy-in from the citizenry, Europe‚Äôs leaders opted for incremental integration through treaties and bureaucratic layering. Monetary union was introduced without full political union. Institutions like the European Commission and the European Central Bank were empowered without always being directly accountable to European citizens. In the words of former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl: ‚ÄúWe decided to go ahead with monetary union because we could not achieve political union.‚Äù Jacques Delors, architect of the Maastricht Treaty, put it more bluntly: ‚ÄúPolitical union will be the consequence of economic integration.‚Äù This approach worked‚Äîuntil it didn‚Äôt. When French and Dutch voters rejected the proposed EU Constitution in 2005, leaders responded not with a public rethinking, but with a workaround: the Lisbon Treaty. Same substance, different packaging. As Val√©ry Giscard d‚ÄôEstaing, who helped draft the original constitution, admitted: ‚ÄúThe proposals remain practically unchanged.‚Äù What emerged was what scholars came to call ‚Äúintegration by stealth.‚Äù Not a conspiracy, but a methodology‚Äîone that produced a powerful administrative apparatus, but a weaker sense of civic ownership. Today‚Äôs EU sits somewhere between a federation and a confederation. Authority is divided. Responsibilities overlap. This process‚Äîof layering authority without fortifying accountability‚Äîhelped build impressive institutions, but left Europe ill-prepared to act decisively when it matters most. It‚Äôs not unlike what we see in business. Think of a large conglomerate owning many subsidiaries. In theory, each subsidiary should have the best of both worlds: the resources and stability of a corporate giant, and the nimbleness of a local operator. Some Berkshire Hathaway companies manage to strike that balance. But in many other cases, it becomes the worst of both worlds‚Äîcorporate headquarters micromanages what it doesn‚Äôt understand, while local managers feel disempowered to lead. The result isn‚Äôt immediate catastrophe. It‚Äôs drift. Underperformance. Missed opportunity. And when a crisis hits, nobody is quite sure who‚Äôs in charge‚Äîor how quickly they‚Äôre allowed to act. A System That Blinks in a Crisis In stable times, the EU functions. Its institutions regulate markets, coordinate standards, and pool technical expertise. But when the world gets messy‚Äîwhen pandemics hit, energy supplies are weaponized, or trade conflicts erupt‚Äîthe EU‚Äôs slow, multi-speed machinery struggles to respond. Take the COVID-19 crisis. The EU struggled to coordinate vaccine procurement, while national interests quickly reasserted themselves, national borders re-erected. Energy policy offered another: the bloc‚Äôs decades-long reliance on Russian gas was well known, yet efforts at diversification remained piecemeal until after Moscow‚Äôs 2022 invasion of Ukraine. On foreign policy, the picture is even starker. While the EU has long aspired to ‚Äústrategic autonomy,‚Äù it continues to rely heavily on U.S. defense guarantees through NATO. Joint military procurement is limited. Diplomacy is often divided. And even where Brussels speaks for the bloc‚Äîon trade or sanctions‚Äîindividual member states can undercut consensus. R. Daniel Kelemen, McCourt Chair at the McCourt School of Public Policy at Georgetown University, once summarized this imbalance clearly: ‚ÄúThe EU can regulate Google, but it cannot stop Putin. That says everything about the imbalance.‚Äù Princeton‚Äôs Andrew Moravcsik has also elucidated, ‚ÄúThe EU‚Äôs intergovernmental system may function well in stable times, but in moments of crisis, its slowness and fragmentation can undermine decisive action.‚Äù This isn‚Äôt just theory. It‚Äôs happened repeatedly. From the Eurozone debt crisis to the migrant crisis, from Syria to Libya to Ukraine, the EU has often arrived late‚Äîor not at all. And its credibility as a geopolitical actor has suffered accordingly. How Others Exploit the Gaps External actors have noticed. Over the past two decades, powers like the United States, China, and Russia have learned to navigate the EU‚Äôs divided structure‚Äîand have strategically exploited those gaps. The United States has frequently bypassed Brussels to negotiate directly with key capitals. During the Iraq War, the Bush administration built a ‚Äúcoalition of the willing‚Äù by engaging newer EU members like Poland and the Czech Republic, sidelining France and Germany. In trade talks, often Washington preferred dealing with the nations that matter most to its interests at the time. Russia has played a long game of energy diplomacy‚Äîcutting bilateral gas deals with Germany while using supply disruptions to pressure Eastern states. The Nord Stream 1, signed in 2005, was a bilateral pipeline deal between Russia and Germany‚Äînegotiated without Brussels. It deepened divisions within the EU just as Eastern states warned that dependency on Russian gas was a strategic mistake. And during crises, such as the 2021 migrant standoff engineered by Belarus, the EU‚Äôs disjointed response only confirmed Moscow‚Äôs strategic calculations. The Chinese Communist Party, too, has worked the EU‚Äôs seams. Its 17+1 initiative engaged Central and Eastern European countries directly, offering infrastructure deals outside of EU frameworks. In 2017, Greece‚Äîafter Chinese investment in its port‚Äîblocked an EU statement criticizing Beijing‚Äôs human rights record. Italy‚Äôs 2019 decision to join the Belt and Road Initiative further exposed Brussels‚Äô lack of cohesion. Then Italy was hit hardest during the pandemic, and has in recent times done an about-face. Even Middle Eastern powers like Qatar and the United Arab Emirates have learned to deal bilaterally‚Äîthrough energy contracts, arms deals, or cultural diplomacy‚Äîwith France, Germany, or Italy, bypassing collective EU positions. Even internally, countries like Hungary and Poland have repeatedly vetoed or delayed joint EU positions on rule of law, migration, and Ukraine sanctions‚Äîfurther weakening the bloc‚Äôs external credibility. And that gap hasn‚Äôt just cost Europe. It‚Äôs cost the world. Would China‚Äôs strategic rise over the past three decades have gone so uncontested if the EU had been a global actor with real geopolitical weight? Would Russia have deepened its military alignment with Beijing if Europe had projected more than regulation? Would the first Iran nuclear deal‚Äîcrafted with heavy EU involvement‚Äîhave been so easily circumvented? When Europe doesn‚Äôt show up as a pillar of power, others shape the order without it. And sometimes, against it. The Shift Toward Sovereignty‚Äîand the Importance of Timing The global mood has changed. The 1990s and early 2000s were characterized by optimism about globalism, supranational governance, and borderless integration‚Äîa window of opportunity for the ‚ÄúEuropean project.‚Äù Today‚Äôs world is more fragmented, more adversarial, and more focused on national sovereignty. From Brexit to Trump, from Eastern Europe to Asia, citizens and leaders are asserting national autonomy. Integration, once assumed to be the future, is now questioned‚Äîeven by former advocates. More than ever, bold reform requires not just treaties, but persuasion‚Äîof citizens, not just elites. And in this climate, systems that can‚Äôt move with clarity risk getting sidelined. That‚Äôs the deeper story behind the 2025 trade deal. It‚Äôs not just about tariffs. It‚Äôs about the difference between having weight and having force. The EU still has enormous assets: population, capital, technological capability, and cultural reach. Yet without institutions that combine legitimacy with the capacity to act, those assets remain relatively inert. As historian Timothy Garton Ash warned back in the year 2000: ‚ÄúEurope‚Äôs drive toward unification threatens just the opposite‚Äîdisunity.‚Äù That paradox remains as yet unresolved. Views expressed in this article are opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of The Epoch Times or ZeroHedge. Tyler Durden Mon, 08/11/2025 - 02:00
